private_information: I hold disks from top to bottom: A, B, C, D, E, F, G where A is the smallest and G is the largest
I can only move the top disk from my stack
left_agent.goal: Move the entire tower of disks from the left peg to the right peg following the rules: move one disk at a time and never place a larger disk on top of a smaller one.

private_information: I can receive the top disk from another peg and I can move my top disk to another peg following the rules
middle_agent.goal: Assist in moving the tower so that all disks end on the right peg in correct order while respecting the movement rules.

private_information: I will be the destination peg for the full tower
right_agent.goal: Receive the full tower of disks on my peg in order A on top down to G at bottom without ever violating the placement rules.

private_information: I coordinate the agents and integrate their local states into a single planning model
I produce the final PDDL domain and problem to be solved with the FastDownwards planner
orchestrator.goal: Produce a valid PDDL domain and problem that solves the Tower of Hanoi instance by moving the full stack from left to right under the movement constraints, with actions kept distinct per peg where appropriate.

rules: Only one disk may be moved at a time
A larger disk may never be placed on a smaller disk
Only the top disk of any peg may be moved

public_information: This is a Tower of Hanoi problem with three pegs named left, middle, and right
There are 7 disks labeled A (smallest) through G (largest)
Initial state: left peg holds the full tower A on top down to G, middle and right pegs are empty
Goal state: right peg should have the full tower A on top down to G, left and middle should be empty
Movement constraints: move one disk at a time and never place a larger disk on top of a smaller disk

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent planning and PDDL. Your job is to integrate the local state reports of the peg agents into a single coherent PDDL domain and PDDL problem targeting the FastDownwards planner. Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that model the Tower of Hanoi rules and the specific 7-disk instance. Keep actions distinct where relevant and ensure the problem encodes the initial and goal configurations precisely. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. You will receive the local state descriptions from three peg agents and the public environment information. Integrate these inputs to produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that can be solved by FastDownwards to move the full tower from left to right. Ensure the domain models pegs, disks, the top-only move constraint, and the size ordering preventing larger-on-smaller placements. Ensure the problem encodes the initial stack on left and the goal stack on right. Enclose the domain in <domain></domain> and the problem in <problem></problem>. If agent reports are partial or use different naming conventions, reconcile them explicitly and keep peg actions and predicates consistent.
